subtitle: A video clip showing a pickup being oblierated by a meteorite in the desert  is merely an excerpt from a Toyota truck commercial.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A video clip shows a meteorite striking a pickup truck in the desert.

title: Goal Line Powder
subtitle: The joke reappears every football season.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Mysterious white powdery substance on a football field is revealed to be the goal line.

title: Are Costco Wholesale Stores Owned by China?
subtitle: Sometimes rumors confuse two businesses with similar names.
author: David Mikkelson

title: Can You Sell a Testicle for $35,000 to $50,000?
subtitle: Not one of the better schemes for those who need cash in a hurry.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A university medical school will pay you upwards of $50,000 for the donation of a testicle.

title: Phony Phone Call
subtitle: Photograph showing President Bush holding a telephone to his ear upside-down is a manipulated one.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Photograph shows President Bush holding a telephone to his ear upside-down.

title: Did General Douglas MacArthur Predict an Interplanetary War?
subtitle: The WWII icon alluded to the possibility that mankind might someday face an extraterrestrial foe.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: During a 1955 speech at West Point, General Douglas MacArthur told assembled cadets: "The next war will be an interplanetary war. The nations of the earth must someday make a common front against attack by people from other planets."

title: Is Arby's Roast Beef 'Liquid Meat'?
subtitle: Rumors claim Arby's roast beef sandwiches are made from paste, gel, powder, or liquid.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Arby's roast beef is made from a paste, gel, powder, or liquid.

title: Is This Man's Name Really Peter Griffin?
subtitle: The photograph has gained popularity in social media clickbait ads that lead to listicles and slideshows that don't end up including the image.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A man in a photograph named Peter Griffin bears a strong resemblance to animated character of the same name.

title: Is the CPR Mannequin Modeled After the Inventor's Deceased Daughter?
subtitle: Many CPR students have been taught to check if a patient is unconscious by gently shaking the doll and calling, "Annie, are you OK?" But was there once a real "Annie"?
author: Snopes Staff
statement: The face of the CPR training mannequin was modeled after the deceased daughter of the doctor who invented it.

title: Did Al Gore Say 'I Invented the Internet'?
subtitle: Despite decades of media mirth-making about the supposed statement, former vice president Al Gore never claimed he "invented the Internet."
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Vice-President Al Gore claimed during a news interview that he "invented" the Internet.

title: Are Rapists Using Lost Children to Lure Victims?
subtitle: Warnings that rapists are employing children pretending to be lost in order to lure victims to them are unsubstantiated.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Rapists are using small children who appear to be lost to lure victims to them.

title: Was 'Amityville Horror' Based on a True Story?
subtitle: "I remember going by that house and how scary it was."
author: Snopes Staff
statement: 'The Amityville Horror' is based on a true story.

title: Amy Bruce Cancer Appeal
subtitle: A 7-year-old girl named Amy Bruce is not dying of lung cancer and a brain tumor and didn't write a poem called 'Slow Dance.'
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Forwarding an e-mail message will help Amy Bruce, a 7-year-old girl dying of lung cancer and a brain tumor.

title: The Ghost Under the Bed
subtitle: A spooky photograph purportedly captures a dead woman who collects the souls of people who don't share her image.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A photograph shows a dead woman who collects the souls of people who don't share her image.

title: Did Marvin Gaye Deliberately Record a Bad Album to Cheat His Ex-Wife Out of Royalties?
subtitle: The album 'Here, My Dear' chronicled the deterioration of Marvin Gaye's marriage into its heartbreaking, bitter, and angry end.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Marvin Gaye deliberately recorded a wretched album designed to sell poorly in order to cheat his ex-wife out of royalties.

title: Fetal Footprint
subtitle: Does a photograph show the imprint of a fetal footprint on its mother's abdomen?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A photograph shows the imprint of a fetal footprint on its mother's abdomen.

title: Did the Yankees Adopt Pinstriped Uniforms to Hide Babe Ruth's Girth?
subtitle: "No other person outside of public life so stirred our imaginations or so captured our affections."
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The New York Yankees adopted pinstriped uniforms in an effort to disguise Babe Ruth's growing waistline.

title: Was Walt Disney Born in Robinson, Illinois?
subtitle: It's a charming story, but the details don't quite add up.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Walt Disney was born in Robinson, Illinois, and named after a helpful townsperson who assisted his parents.

title: Was a Giant Skeleton Uncovered in Saudi Arabia?
subtitle: Gas exploration in Saudi Arabia reportedly uncovered human remains of gigantic proportions.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The skeleton of a giant human was uncovered during gas exploration in Saudi Arabia.

title: Is Swiffer WetJet Toxic to Pets?
subtitle: An anonymous message warned of a dangerous ingredient lurking in a common household cleaning product.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The Swiffer WetJet poses a general danger to dogs and other household pets.

title: The 'Banned' Book of Dr. Seuss
subtitle: Did Dr. Seuss once write a children's book since banned due to its references to suicide and violence?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Dr. Seuss once wrote a children's book since banned due to its references to suicide and violence.

title: Jane Fonda at Sir Scott's Oasis Steakhouse
subtitle: Viral story claimed Jane Fonda and Ted Turner were refused service in a restaurant run by a Vietnam War veteran.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Jane Fonda and Ted Turner were refused service in a restaurant run by a Vietnam War veteran.

title: Albert Einstein Switches Places with His Chauffeur
subtitle: "Why, this is so simple even my driver could explain it to you."
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Albert Einstein switched places with his chauffeur for a speaking engagement, then fielded a question directed to the man the audience thought was him.

title: Holiday for Atheists
subtitle: A judge supposedly told a non-religious, holiday-seeking plaintiff that atheists already have their own holiday: April 1.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A judge told an atheist plaintiff who challenged religious holidays that atheists already have their own holiday: April 1.

title: Do Super Bowl Toilet Flushes Break Sewage Systems?
subtitle: Sewage systems of major cities have supposedly broken due to the tremendous number of toilets being flushed simultaneously at halftime of the Super Bowl.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Sewage systems of major cities have broken due to the tremendous number of toilets being flushed simultaneously at halftime of the Super Bowl.

title: Did a Reporter Ask Doug Williams How Long He'd Been a Black Quarterback?
subtitle: "Doug, are you upset about all the questions about your being the first black quarterback in the Super Bowl?"
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Before Super Bowl XXII in 1988, a reporter asked Washington Redskins quarterback Doug Williams, "How long have you been a black quarterback?"

title: Are Abbott and Costello Members of Baseball's Hall of Fame?
subtitle: For two men who never set foot on a professional baseball field in any official capacity, that would be quite an honor.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Comedians Bud Abbott and Lou Costello are members of the National Baseball Hall of Fame.

title: Why Is Men's Underwear Called 'BVDs'?
subtitle: In the absence of a logical explanation for something so commonplace, people invented their own meanings.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Men's underwear is referred to as 'BVDs' because the term is an abbreviation of the phrase 'Boy's Ventilated Drawers.'

title: Did a Pilot Use an Axe to Reenter the Cockpit?
subtitle: Rumor has it that a commercial airline pilot who accidentally locked himself out of the cockpit had to hack down the door with a fire axe to regain entry.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A commercial airline pilot who accidentally locked himself out of the cockpit had to hack down the door with a fire axe to regain entry.

title: Did Bad Officiating Kill Fran Tarkenton's Father?
subtitle: Rumor holds that bad referees' calls during an NFL playoff game contributed to the death of Vikings quarterback Fran Tarkenton's father.
author: David Mikkelson

title: Was a Child Named After Robert Matthews, 9/11 Rescuer?
subtitle: A supposed account by a woman who said she named her child after the rescuer who died while saving her and others at the World Trade Center on Sept. 11.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A woman named her child after the rescuer who died while saving her and others at the World Trade Center on 9/11.

title: Does Shaving Hair Make It Grow Back Thicker?
subtitle: As much as we shampoo it, style it, cut it, and fret over it, hair continues to be a mystery to us.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Shaving makes your hair grow back thicker, faster, and fuller.

title: Will a Few Drops of Visine Taken Internally Cause Diarrhea?
subtitle: Contrary to common belief, a few drops of Visine brand eye drops taken internally will not cause diarrhea.  But swallowing it can produce much more serious medical problems.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A few drops of Visine brand eye drops taken internally will induce uncontrollable diarrhea.

title: Was a Teenager Killed by a Plastic Dashboard Jesus?
subtitle: "We're just glad our daughter had Jesus in her heart when she died."
statement: A teen died in a car crash when a plastic Jesus dashboard ornament embedded in her chest.

title: Daddy Longlegs Is the World's Most Poisonous Animal?
subtitle: Let's fact-check that.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The daddy longlegs is the "world's most poisonous animal."

title: Wally Pipp's Career-Ending 'Headache'
subtitle: Baseball folklore holds that Lou Gehrig's famous consecutive game streak began when the Yankees' first baseman Wally Pipp sat out a game with a headache.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Lou Gehrig's consecutive game streak began when Yankee first baseman Wally Pipp sat out a game with a headache.

title: Trade Bait
subtitle: Unfortunately, even the national pastime is known for episodes of cruelty inflicted upon its practitioners.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Dodgers outfielder Cal Abrams was ordered to publicly berate the Reds' manager, then was traded to that team a few days later.

title: Is a 'Mars Spectacular' Coming Soon?
subtitle: The planet Mars will not be making a once-in-our-lifetimes, remarkably close approach to Earth on August 27.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The planet Mars will make a once-in-our-lifetimes, remarkably close approach to Earth on August 27.

title: Was Fidel Castro Given a Tryout by the Washington Senators?
subtitle: There is no record that Fidel Castro ever played, much less starred, on any baseball team.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Future Cuban revolutionary leader Fidel Castro was once given a tryout by the Washington Senators baseball team.

title: Is Geraldo Rivera's Real Name 'Jerry Rivers'?
subtitle: Of all the professional criticisms leveled at Geraldo Rivera over the years, one of the most common is also the one of the most unfair.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Television journalist Geraldo Rivera was born Jerry Rivers but changed his name to appeal to Latino viewers.

title: Quran 9:11
subtitle: Does Quranic verse 9:11 speak of the 'wrath of the Eagle cleansing the lands of Allah'?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Quranic verse 9:11 speaks of the "wrath of the Eagle cleansing the lands of Allah."

title: Is This an Outtake from the Apollo 11 Moon Landing?
subtitle: An unearthed video clip appears to show a studio-produced 'outtake' of the first manned moon landing.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A video clip shows a NASA studio-produced 'outtake' of the first manned moon landing.

title: 'Crying Baby' Serial Killer Victim Lure
subtitle: Warning holds that a serial killer is luring women from their homes by playing a recording of a crying baby.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A serial killer is luring women from their homes by playing a recording of a crying baby.

title: Did Native Americans Give NASA a Message to Take to the Moon?
subtitle: The story of how a joke becomes a legend.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Native Americans provided NASA with a cryptic message to take to the moon.

title: Was Bill Clinton a 'Felonious Draft Dodger'?
subtitle: Bill Clinton's questionable activities during the Vietnam-era draft did not make him the 'first pardoned federal felon ever to serve as President of the U.S.'
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Bill Clinton was the "first pardoned federal felon ever to serve as President of the U.S."

title: Did Clark Gable Kill a Pedestrian While Driving Drunk?
subtitle: Rumor holds that the MGM star killed a pedestrian while inebriated, but the studio conspired with the DA's office to cover up the accident.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Clark Gable killed a pedestrian while driving drunk, but MGM covered up the accident and sent another man to jail in his place.

title: Did a U.S. Ship Really Display This Message?
subtitle: A photograph appears to show the words "FUCK IRAQ" displayed on the deck of a U.S. aircraft carrier.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Photograph shows sailors spelling out the words 'FUCK IRAQ' on the deck of a U.S. aircraft carrier.

title: Did Typhoid Mary Cause the Deaths of Thousands of People?
subtitle: Mary Mallon has come to be so strongly identified with the spread of disease that it is now commonly believed she was responsible for hundreds, if not thousands, of deaths.
statement: Typhoid Mary caused the deaths of thousands of people.

title: Does This Photograph Show President Bush Reading a Book Upside-Down?
subtitle: The book shown in this photograph is 'America: A Patriotic Primer,' by Lynne Cheney
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A photograph captures President George W. Bush holding a book upside-down in a classroom.

title: Post 9/11 Baby Boom
subtitle: Did the birth rate shoot up nine months after September 11?
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Hospitals experienced a sharp increase in births nine months after September 11.

title: Do Brothel Laws Outlaw College Sororities?
subtitle: We have heard from many students who were convinced their particular university lacks a sorority because of local "law."
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Sororities are outlawed on certain campuses because local "brothel laws" prohibit more than a specified number of females from living together.

title: Are Love Bugs the Result of an Experiment Gone Wrong?
subtitle: How the sex-crazed March fly proliferated in the United States.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: "Love bugs" are the result of a genetic experiment gone wrong at the University of Florida.

title: Just Deserts
subtitle: Sometimes it doesn't matter whether you use language correctly, because people will think you're wrong even when you're not.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A person who gets what he deserves is said to have received his "just desserts."

title: Was Lisa Lopes Murdered?
subtitle: Rumor holds that TLC's Lisa Lopes was murdered in a revenge killing because she had caused the death of a Honduran youngster.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: TLC's Lisa "Left-Eye" Lopes was murdered in a revenge killing.

title: Did Shakira Say 'I'd Rather Have Pigs Listen to My Music Than Israelis'?
subtitle: The false attribution of racist screeds to celebrities is unfortunately not a rare phenomenon.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: During an MTV appearance, singer Shakira said she'd rather have pigs listening to her music than Israelis.

title: Did Saudis Fly Out of the U.S. While Airspace Was Still Closed after 9/11?
subtitle: Rumor holds that a secret flight whisked prominent Saudis and Osama bin Laden's relatives out of the USA during a ban on air travel.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Secret flights whisked bin Laden family members and Saudi nationals out of the U.S. immediately after September 11 while a general ban on air travel was still in effect, and before the FBI had any opportunity to question any of the passengers.

title: Dragnet: 'Just the Facts. Ma'am'
subtitle: Did Dragnet's Sgt. Joe Friday character frequently implore female informants to provide 'Just the facts, ma'am'?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: 'Dragnet''s Sgt. Joe Friday character frequently implored female informants to provide "Just the facts, ma'am."

title: Was Winston Churchill Born in a Ladies' Room During a Dance?
subtitle: When it comes to trivia, reality often runs a distant second to fascinating apocrypha.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Winston Churchill was born in a ladies' room during a dance.

title: Did Captain Kangaroo and Lee Marvin Fight at Iwo Jima?
subtitle: Lee Marvin and Bob 'Captain Kangaroo' Keeshan were both in the military during World War II, but they didn't fight together at Iwo Jima or any other engagement.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Lee Marvin, actor, and Bob Keeshan, television's "Captain Kangaroo" were World War II veterans who fought together at Iwo Jima.

title: Did Pepsi Omit 'Under God' from the Pledge of Allegiance?
subtitle: A 17-year-old rumor about the Pledge of Allegiance that never had anything to do with Pepsi continues to dog the soft drink company.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A new Pepsi soda can design omitted the words "under God" from the Pledge of Allegiance.

title: Does the U.S. Presidential Seal Change in Wartime?
subtitle: History buffs love to pass around this rumor.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: During wartime, the Seal of the President of the United States is modified so that the eagle's head faces the opposite direction.

title: Have Women Been Killed by Poisoned Perfume Samples?
subtitle: A warning from "Glen Eagles" hospital about the deaths of women who sniffed poisoned perfume samples is an old hoax.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Glen Eagles hospital issued an urgent warning because seven women have died after sniffing perfume samples received in the mail.

title: Did ABC News Ban Flag Lapel Pins?
subtitle: Misunderstandings about prior policy led to the rumor that ABC  had banned their on-air news personnel from wearing American flag pins after 9/11.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: ABC banned on-air news personnel from wearing American flag pins after 9/11.

title: Does Being an 'Only Son' Exempt You from a Military Draft?
subtitle: Contrary to common belief, being an only child (or an only son) does not automatically exempt you from military service in the U.S.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Being an only child (or an only son) automatically exempts you from military service in the U.S.

title: Unburned Pentagon Bible
subtitle: Was an unburned Bible found amidst the wreckage of the Pentagon?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: An unburned Bible was found amidst the charred wreckage of the Pentagon after the September 11 terrorist attack.

title: Does Most Domestic Violence Occur on Super Bowl Sunday?
subtitle: "Women's shelters and hotlines are flooded with more calls from victims on Super Bowl Sunday than on any other day of the year."
author: Snopes Staff
statement: More women are victims of domestic violence on Super Bowl Sunday than on any other day of the year.

title: Is This Shark Attacking a British Navy Diver?
subtitle: Let's take a closer look.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Photograph shows a shark attacking a British Navy diver.

title: Australian Gun Stats
subtitle: Do statistics demonstrate that crime rates in Australia have increased substantially since the government instituted a gun buy-back program in 1997?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Statistics demonstrate that crime rates in Australia have increased substantially since the government there instituted a gun buy-back program in 1997.

title: Should You Wait an Hour After Eating to Swim?
subtitle: Childhood is fraught with dangers, both real and imagined.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Those who go swimming less than one hour after eating will be taken by a cramp and drown.

title: Are These Entries from a Suicidal Teenager's Diary?
subtitle: The message about adolescents and suicide doesn't need the over-the-top fictionalization this treatment gave it.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Real diary entries of a rejected teen who subsequently had tragedy strike her family show the lead-up to suicide.

title: Was the World Series Named for a Newspaper?
subtitle: Legend holds that baseball's championship competition is known as the "World Series" because it was originally sponsored by the New York World newspaper.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Baseball's championship competition is known as the "World Series" because it was originally sponsored by the

title: Will Placing a Penny on the Tracks Derail a Train?
subtitle: "I smashed a penny on the railroad tie ... and was advised by someone that I could have derailed the train."
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A penny placed on the tracks will derail a train.

title: The Cost(ner) of Love
subtitle: Rumor holds that the Baltimore Orioles deliberately created a lighting malfunction before a 1997 game to keep Cal Ripken's consecutive game streak intact.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: In August 1997, the Baltimore Orioles deliberately created a lighting malfunction before a game to keep Cal Ripken's consecutive game streak intact.

title: Are There Two Unreleased Beatles Songs?
subtitle: Rumor has it that the Beatles recorded the songs 'Colliding Circles' and 'Pink Litmus Paper Shirt' which remain unreleased to this day.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The Beatles recorded songs entitled "Colliding Circles," "Left Is Right (And Right Is Wrong)," "Pink Litmus Paper Shirt," and "Deckchair," all of which remain unreleased to this day.

title: Walt Disney's Final Instructions
subtitle: "In a bizarre turn, one that underscores the anxiety and paranoia of his last days, Walt made a series of films to be shown after his death."
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Walt Disney prepared a film to be viewed by Disney executives after his death, in which he gave them all instructions about how to run their areas of the company.

title: Romantic Encounter with a Necrophiliac
subtitle: A girl's unusual medical condition led to the discovery that the boy she'd been intimate with had been having sex with corpses.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A girl's unusual medical condition led to the discovery that the boy she'd been intimate with had been having sex with (or eating) corpses.

title: Was John Hanson the First U.S. President?
subtitle: "I can hear you now - John who?"
author: David Mikkelson
statement: John Hanson was the first President of the United States of America.

title: Etymology of 'News'
subtitle: The English word 'news' is said to derive from an acronym formed from the words 'north,' east,' 'west,' and 'south.'
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The word

title: Etymology of Hot Dog
subtitle: Was the term 'hot dog' coined by a sports cartoonist who couldn't spell 'dachshund'?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The term "hot dog" was coined in the early 1900s by a cartoonist who couldn't spell "dachshund."

title: Are Government Regulations for Cabbage 27,000 Words Long?
subtitle: Some myths are too deeply cherished to be displaced by mere fact.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A government memo regulating the sale of cabbages ran close to 27,000 words.

title: Why Does Frau Blucher's Name Scare Horses in 'Young Frankenstein'?
subtitle: For some of us, the desire to believe we've been let in on a piece of secret knowledge can overpower our good sense.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The horses in 'Young Frankenstein' react violently to mention of Frau Blucher's name because it means 'glue' in German.

title: She's in the Attic!
subtitle: "She couldn't remember her lines, her delivery was amateurish, and the more she rehearsed, the worse she got."
author: David Mikkelson
statement: An actress' stage performance as Anne Frank was so bad that audience members yelled 'She's in the attic!' when Nazi soldiers arrived onstage.

title: Did Marilyn Monroe Have Six Toes?
subtitle: The extra 'something' that Marilyn possessed doesn't appear to have been a toe.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Marilyn Monroe had six toes on each foot.

title: Can Coca-Cola Dissolve Teeth?
subtitle: Imagine what it could do to your stomach!
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A tooth left in a glass of Coca-Cola will dissolve overnight.

title: Are These the Final Words of the Challenger Crew?
subtitle: Reports of a secret tape recorded aboard the doomed space shuttle Challenger that captured the final panic-stricken moments of the crew raised suspicions of a cover-up.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A secret tape recorded aboard the doomed space shuttle Challenger captured the final panic-stricken moments of the crew.

title: The Secret Words
subtitle: Rumor has it that Groucho Marx made a risque wisecrack about his cigar to a female 'You Bet Your Life' contestant with 17 children.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Groucho Marx made a risque wisecrack about his cigar to a female You Bet Your Life contestant with 19 children.

title: Does Chewing Gum Take Seven Years to Digest?
subtitle: This oft-repeated claim may stem from genuine confusion over a term commonly applied to chewing gum: indigestible.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Chewing gum takes seven years to pass through the human digestive system.

title: Is Ordinary Use of Canola Oil Dangerous?
subtitle: Rapeseed oil has been used for cooking for centuries in Europe, India, China, and Japan.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Ordinary use of canola oil is dangerous to consumers.

title: Kentucky Fried Rat
subtitle: The frequency of attachment of an urban legend to the largest company or corporation is so common as to be considered a law of urban folklore.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A customer who picked up some fried chicken from a fast food outlet discovered that an unusual-tasting piece was actually a batter-fried rat.

title: Rock Star 'Stomach Pump' Legend
subtitle: Urban legend describes a rock star who collapses at a party and has a pint of semen pumped from his stomach.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: After collapsing at a post-concert party, a rock star was rushed to an emergency room, where doctors pumped a pint of semen out of his (or her) stomach.

title: Were Disney Studios Required to Convert into a Hospital?
subtitle: Requiring that new construction projects be adaptable to other uses is not an unheard of condition.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: In order to obtain financing from bankers for his new Burbank studios, Walt Disney had to promise to construct a facility that could easily be converted into a hospital.

title: Do McDonald's Shakes Contain Yucky Non-Food Substances?
subtitle: Despite long-held rumors, McDonald's desserts do not substitute primary ingredients such as milk and fruit.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: McDonald's beverages contain yucky non-food substances.

title: Did the Word 'Picnic' Originate with Lynchings?
subtitle: Neither the concept nor the word 'picnic' originated with crowds gathering to witness extrajudicial racial hangings.
statement: The word 'picnic' originated with crowds gathering to witness lynchings.

title: Is 'Puff the Magic Dragon' About Marijuana?
subtitle: 'Puff the Magic Dragon' is what its writers have always claimed it to be: a song about the innocence of childhood lost.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The Peter, Paul & Mary tune "Puff, the Magic Dragon" is a coded song about marijuana.

title: The Meaning of 'Fire and Rain'
subtitle: Does the song 'Fire and Rain' chronicle the death of singer James Taylor's girlfriend in a plane crash?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The lyrics of James Taylor's "Fire and Rain" chronicle his reaction to the death of his girlfriend in a plane crash.

title: Life in the 1500s
subtitle: A list purported to offer the origins of numerous common English-language sayings dating to the 1500s.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: The numerous current sayings listed in a "Life in the 1500s" article sprang from ordinary living conditions in that era.

title: Thomas Crapper: Inventor of the Flush Toilet?
subtitle: Despite being so credited in common lore, Thomas Crapper did not actually invent the flush toilet.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A man named Thomas Crapper invented the flush toilet.

title: Does a Urine-Revealing Pool Chemical Exist?
subtitle: Kids have long been warned about a chemical in swimming pools that reveals the presence of urine.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A special compound added to the water in swimming pools will reveal the presence of urine and catch those who pee in the pool.

title: Do the Acids in Coca-Cola Make It Harmful to Drink?
subtitle: Nearly all carbonated soft drinks contain carbonic acid.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The acids in Coca-Cola make it harmful to drink.

title: Is 'Ring Around the Rosie' About the Black Plague?
subtitle: People love to create and spread invented backstories for simple nursery rhymes.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The nursery rhyme "Ring Around the Rosie" is a coded reference to the Black Plague.

title: Three Wise Men
subtitle: Does the Bible say that three wise men visited Jesus in a stable?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The Bible says that three wise men traveled from afar on camels to visit the infant Jesus as he lay in the manger.

title: Did Donald Trump Have a Horse Thief Ancestor?
subtitle: Perennially  circulated bit of political humor holds that a distant relative of a prominent politician was a horse thief and a train robber.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A distant relative of Donald Trump was a horse thief and a train robber.

title: Did Marilyn Monroe Wear a Size 16 Dress?
subtitle: Some contemporary celebrities seem to be fond of invoking this "fact."
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Marilyn Monroe wore a size 16 dress.

title: Did a Government Official Order the Firing of Cattle Guards?
subtitle: Old political joke holds that a clueless U.S. government official ordered half the cattle guards in Colorado be fired.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A clueless U.S. government official ordered half the cattle guards in Colorado be fired.

title: How Long Must Students Wait for an Absent Professor?
subtitle: Ten minutes? Fifteen minutes? Until the scheduled end of class?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: All colleges have regulations specifying how long students must wait if an instructor fails to appear, and these wait times vary depending upon the academic rank of the instructor.

title: NASA's 'Astronaut Pen'
subtitle: Space race legend claims NASA spent millions of dollars developing an 'astronaut pen' that would work in outer space, while the Soviets solved the same problem by simply using pencils.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: NASA spent millions of dollars developing an 'astronaut pen' that would work in outer space, while the Soviets fixed the problem much more cheaply and quickly by using pencils.

title: Did a Male Titanic Passenger Pose as a Woman to Get on a Lifeboat?
subtitle: Only one verified case of an adult male passenger's using an article of women's clothing to secure a place on a lifeboat turned up in the lengthy inquiries.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A man sneaked his way onto one of the

title: Did Crime Rates Plummet When the Beatles' Debuted on 'Ed Sullivan'?
subtitle: When a sarcastic wisecrack becomes fact, print the legend.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: During the Beatles' first appearance on 'The Ed Sullivan Show', crime rates plummeted all over the U.S.

title: Facebook Cancellation Notice
subtitle: A warning alerts social media users that Facebook is about to cancel their accounts if they don't like or share a particular message.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Facebook is overloaded and is about to cancel the accounts of users who don't like or share a particular message:

title: Are the Lyrics to 'Louie, Louie' Obscene?
subtitle: The FBI spent years and untold amounts of money investigating a salacious rumor that they could never run to ground.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The lyrics to the song "Louie Louie" contain multiple obscene references.

title: Martin Luther King Stamp
subtitle: Is the U.S. Postal Service discontinuing the Martin Luther King stamp?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The United States Postal Service's new "I Have a Dream" stamp honoring Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. will be discontinued and recalled if not enough postal customers purchase them.

title: Can Pull Tabs Be Exchanged for Time on Dialysis Machines?
subtitle: "A false rumor that has plagued the National Kidney Foundation (NKF) and the aluminum industry for decades..."
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Pull tabs from aluminum cans have special redemption value for time on dialysis machines.

title: Breast Gazing Healthy
subtitle: Did The New England Journal of Medicine claim that ogling women's breasts is good for a man's health?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: According to a study published in The New England Journal of Medicine, "ogling women's breasts is good for a man's health."

title: Do Anti-Perspirants Cause Breast Cancer?
subtitle: The American Cancer Society is not aware of any evidence that shows substances in deodorants or antiperspirants to be toxic or that cause DNA damage that could lead to cancer.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Anti-perspirants have been identified as the leading cause of breast cancer.

title: Was Ronald Reagan Slated to Play the Lead in 'Casablanca'?
subtitle: You can't believe everything you read -- no matter when it may have been published.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Ronald Reagan was the original choice to play a lead role in the 1942 film 'Casablanca.'

title: Is Throwing Rice at Weddings Bad for Birds?
subtitle: An old rumor warns that discarded rice eaten by birds can expand in their tiny birdy stomachs and kill them.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Wedding guests should refrain from throwing rice at newly-wedded couples because the rice kills birds who eat it.

title: Is John Dillinger's Penis on Display at the Smithsonian?
subtitle: Someone should start a museum to house all the non-existent things that thousands of people have sworn they've seen.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Gangster John Dillinger's exceptionally large penis is housed in one of the Smithsonian museums in Washington, D.C.

title: Buddy Holly and The Crickets
subtitle: Was Buddy Holly's group named 'The Crickets' because a cricket appeared on one of their songs?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Buddy Holly's group named themselves "The Crickets" because the sound of a chirping cricket accidentally appeared on one of their recordings.

title: Did Aladdin Ask Teenagers to Take Off Their Clothes?
subtitle: The 1992 animated classic is one of many Disney films with questionable conspiracy theories.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: In the film Aladdin, the hero whispers, "Good teenagers, take off your clothes."

title: Was That Walt Disney's Face Inside the Haunted Mansion?
subtitle: A classic piece of Disneyland lore.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The image projected onto one of the singing busts in the Haunted Mansion's graveyard is Walt Disney himself.

title: Can Coca-Cola Prevent Pregnancy?
subtitle: Using Coke as a spermicide has been part of contraceptive lore at least since the 1950s.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Coca-Cola is an effective contraceptive.

title: Do Orthodox Jews Have Marital Relations Through a Hole in a Sheet?
subtitle: Let's fact-check that.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Orthodox jews engage in marital relations through a hole in a sheet.

title: NASA Discovers a 'Lost Day' in Time?
subtitle: NASA scientists did not find a 'missing day' in time and thereby prove Biblical accounts to be true.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: NASA scientists discovered a "missing" day in time that corresponds to Biblical accounts of the sun's standing still in the sky.

title: The Founding of Stanford University
subtitle: Legend asserts that Mr. and Mrs. Leland Stanford decide to found their own university after being rebuffed by Harvard's president.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Mr. and Mrs. Leland Stanford decided to found their own university after being rebuffed by Harvard's president.

title: Did Phil Spector Record an Unreleasable Song to 'Screw' His Former Partner?
subtitle: Spector was an American record producer of the 1960s who was described by the writer Tom Wolfe as the
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Phil Spector deliberately recorded a unreleasable song called 'The Screw' in order to cheat his former partner out of court-ordered royalty payments.

title: Did Buddy Holly Die in an Airplane Called 'American Pie'?
subtitle: The single-engine plane carrying Buddy Holly, the Big Bopper and Ritchie Valens crashed in an Iowa corn field the night before they were to appear at the Moorhead Armory.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The airplane that carried Buddy Holly to his death was named 'American Pie.'

title: Did a Woman Become Pregnant from a Civil War Bullet?
subtitle: This legend has a long and tortuous history stretching back nearly 150 years.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A woman became pregnant from being struck by a bullet that had passed through the scrotum of a Civil War soldier.

title: Did Oprah Winfrey Throw Tommy Hilfiger Off Her Show for Making a Racist Comment?
subtitle: Oprah Winfrey supposedly kicked designer Tommy Hilfiger off her show when he announced, "If I knew that blacks and Asians were going to wear my clothes, I would have never designed them."
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Designer Tommy Hilfiger stated that blacks and Asians shouldn't wear his clothes.

title: Does Billy the Burlap Bag Boy Need Your Help?
subtitle: The sad tale of a little boy with a burlap sack full of leaves for a body.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Little Billy Evans needs your help to obtain a real body to replace the burlap sack full of leaves that now serves as his trunk.

title: Lobster Love
subtitle: A juvenile account of a woman who was infested with shrimp after masturbating with a lobster.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: The lobster with which a woman was masturbating defecated into her vagina, implanting brine shrimp eggs which hatched inside

title: Why Does Washington, D.C., Have No 'J' Street?
subtitle: Old historical legends holds that architect Pierre L'Enfant omitted 'J' Street from his plans for Washington, D.C., because he disliked John Jay.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Washington, D.C., has no 'J' Street because city designer Pierre L'Enfant bore a grudge against Chief Justice John Jay.

title: Did an Actress Die During the Filming of 'Goldfinger'?
subtitle: The sight of the dead, gold-painted girl in 'Goldfinger' is one of filmdom's most memorable images.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The actress who portrayed Jill Masterson in the James Bond film

title: Is This a Real List of Crimes Associated with Members of Congress?
subtitle: A shocking list was published without any sources or supporting documentation.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: List details crimes and disturbing backgrounds associated with members of the U.S. Congress, the NFL, or the NBA.

title: Is 'Xmas' a Modern and Disrespectful Abbreviation for 'Christmas'?
subtitle: The words "Christ" and "Christmas" have been abbreviated in English since long before the modern 'Xmas' came to be commonly used.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The term 'Xmas' is a modern and disrespectful abbreviation for 'Christmas.'

title: Smithsonian Barbie
subtitle: A humorous rejection letter was purportedly sent by the Smithsonian in response to an amateur paleontologist's submission of a Malibu Barbie head.
statement: The Smithsonian sent a rejection letter in response to an amateur paleontologist's submission of a Malibu Barbie head as a prehistoric find.

title: Is the Neiman Marcus Cookie Story True?
subtitle: According to legend, a woman sought sweet revenge after being charged $250 by Neiman Marcus for a cookie recipe.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Woman gains revenge after being charged $250 by Neiman Marcus for a cookie recipe.

title: Can Turkeys Drown in the Rain?
subtitle: Are domesticated turkeys really that stupid?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Domesticated turkeys are so lacking in intelligence that they will look up at falling rain until they drown.

title: Were Dr. Seuss and Kurt Vonnegut College Classmates?
subtitle: It might be difficult to think of two more renowned but dissimilar American authors than Kurt Vonnegut and Dr. Seuss.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Authors Dr. Seuss and Kurt Vonnegut, Jr. were college classmates and fraternity brothers.

title: Did a Cursed Mummy Sink with the Titanic?
subtitle: The ancient artifact that inspired this ghost story can still be seen at the British Museum.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The

title: Hoover Dam Entombments
subtitle: The myth of the concrete pour too important to halt to fish out a mere body is just that, a myth.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Bodies of workmen are entombed in Hoover Dam.

title: The Obstinate Lighthouse
subtitle: Old maritime legend describes an aircraft carrier that unknowingly attempted to bully a lighthouse into moving out of its way.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: An aircraft carrier unknowingly attempted to bully a lighthouse into moving out of its way.

title: Was the Mayonnaise on a Chicken Sandwich Actually a Tumor?
subtitle: "It turns out that the piece of chicken contained a tumor, and when the woman bit into it it exploded, releasing some kind of pus-like substance."
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The mayonnaise oozing from a chicken sandwich turned out to be pus from a tumor in the chicken.

title: Is Dihydrogen Monoxide Dangerous?
subtitle: The dihydrogen monoxide hoax shows that even the most innocuous of substances can be made to sound like a dangerous threat to human life.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Dihydrogen monoxide is a dangerous chemical that should be banned.

title: Child Abduction from Theme Park Thwarted by Shoes
subtitle: Urban legend holds that an attempted abduction of a child from a mall or amusement park was thwarted because the kidnappers neglected to change the child's shoes.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: An attempted abduction of a child from a mall or amusement park was thwarted because the kidnappers forgot to change the child's shoes.

title: Was Coca-Cola Carbonated by Accident?
subtitle: Did Coca-Cola's inventor mix his syrup with soda water because a drugstore clerk made a mistake?
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Coca-Cola became a carbonated drink when a soda jerk accidentally mixed Coca-Cola syrup with soda water.

title: Was the 'New Coke' Fiasco Just a Clever Marketing Ploy?
subtitle: It's almost inconceivable that a company of the size and scope of Coca-Cola could make a mistake on the scale of the one it made in 1985.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Coca-Cola halted production of its flagship beverage in 1985 and introduced New Coke in its place as a marketing ploy to combat declining market share and rekindle interest in the original drink.

title: Did the Chevrolet Nova Fail to Sell in Spanish-Speaking Countries?
subtitle: Classic business legend holds that the Chevrolet Nova sold poorly in Spanish-speaking countries because of a translation snafu.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The Chevrolet Nova sold poorly in Spanish-speaking countries because its name translates as "doesn't go" in Spanish.

title: Did Lewis Carroll Send Queen Victoria a Mathematics Text?
subtitle: According to legend, the author of 'Alice in Wonderland' prankishly dispatched a copy of one of his mathematics texts to an admiring Queen Victoria.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The author of 'Alice in Wonderland' prankishly sent an admiring Queen Victoria a copy of one of his mathematics texts.

title: Egg Balancing on the Equinox
subtitle: It is not true that a special property of the equinox allows eggs (or brooms) to be balanced on their ends that day.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A special property of the equinox allows eggs (or brooms) to be balanced on their ends that day.

title: Equestrian Statue Code
subtitle: Does the number of hooves lifted into the air on equestrian statues reveal how the riders died?
author: Snopes Staff
statement: The number of hooves lifted into the air on equestrian statues reveals how the riders died.

title: Hindu Red Dot
subtitle: What does the red dot on a Hindu's forehead mean?
author: Snopes Staff
statement: The red dot on a Hindu woman's forehead is nothing more than an indicator of her marital status.

title: Did Donald Duck Call Daffy Duck the 'N-Word'?
subtitle: Let's fact-check that.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: In the "dueling pianos" scene of

title: Immaculate Conception
subtitle: Does the term 'Immaculate Conception' refer to the birth of Jesus?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The term "Immaculate Conception" refers to the conception of Jesus by the Virgin Mary.

title: Are Immigrants Exempt from Paying Taxes?
subtitle: Claims that the U.S. government grants multi-year tax exemptions to immigrants are variations of decades-old anti-immigrant rumors.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: The U.S. government grants tax holidays to certain favored groups of immigrants and provides them with free housing, new cars, and clothing allowances.

title: Alabama's Slice of Pi
subtitle: Did the state legislature of Alabama redefine the value of pi according to Biblical precepts?
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Responding to pressure from religious groups, Alabama's state legislature redefined the value of pi from "3.14159..." to "3" in order to bring it in line with Biblical precepts.

title: Is This How Janet Reno Defined a 'Cultist'?
subtitle: "It's probably not surprising that Janet Reno has attracted the ravings of a subterranean lunatic fringe."
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Janet Reno provided her definition of a 'cultist' during a '60 Minutes' interview in 1994.

title: Good Luck, Mr. Gorsky!
subtitle: Neil Armstrong supposedly offered a cryptic remark to a 'Mr. Gorsky' during the Apollo 11 moon landing.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Neil Armstrong cryptically uttered "Good luck, Mr. Gorsky" as he first stepped onto the moon

title: Richard Gere and the Gerbil
subtitle: Hoary urban legend reports a celebrity was taken to a hospital emergency room to have a gerbil removed from his rectum.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Richard Gere was taken to a hospital emergency room to have a gerbil removed from his rectum.

title: Are You a Cop?
subtitle: Must law enforcement officers answer truthfully when asked 'Are you a cop'?
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Prostitutes can safely challenge johns with the question "Are you a cop?" because law enforcement officers must answer truthfully.

title: Did Donald Trump Pay Off a Good Samaritan's Mortgage?
subtitle: Updated version of old urban legend claims Donald Trump rewarded a stranger who helped him change a flat tire by paying off that helpful person's mortgage.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A stranger who stopped to change a tire on a disabled limo was rewarded for his efforts when the vehicle's passenger, Donald Trump, paid off his mortgage.

title: Is 'Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds' Code for LSD?
subtitle: Was the "hidden" acrostic in the famous Beatles song a coincidence or a cheeky pun?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: John Lennon deliberately chose the song title

title: Clinton Body Bags
subtitle: Decades-old political rumor claims Bill Clinton quietly did away with several dozen people who possessed incriminating evidence about him.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Bill Clinton has quietly done away with several dozen people who possessed incriminating evidence about him.

title: Did a Stuntman Die in 'Ben-Hur'?
subtitle: Rumor holds that a stuntman was killed during the filming of the chariot race scene in the 1959 version of 'Ben-Hur,' and that his death was left in the movie's final cut.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A stuntman was killed during the filming of the chariot race scene in the 1959 version of 'Ben-Hur' and that his death was left in the final cut.

title: Does a Ghost Boy Appear in 'Three Men and a Baby'?
subtitle: The film 'Three Men and a Baby' contains no spectral appearances from a dead little boy -- or anyone else.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The ghostly image of a boy who died in the home where

title: The Beatles' Butcher Cover
subtitle: Did the Beatles plan the 'butcher cover' album as a protest against Capitol Records?
author: David Mikkelson

title: Sinko de Mayo
subtitle: Humor about cargo lost in the Titanic's sinking leading to the creation of the Cinco de Mayo observance has been taken too literally by some.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Cargo lost in the Titanic's sinking led to the creation of the Cinco de Mayo observance.

title: Soupy Sales' Smutty Jokes
subtitle: Soupy Sales was legendary for sneaking off-color humor into his children's TV show.  But did he really?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Soupy Sales routinely sneaked smutty jokes into his television program.

title: Did Walt Disney Receive a Dishonorable Discharge?
subtitle: Some legends claim he was proud of it.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Walt Disney received a dishonorable discharge from the military during World War I.

title: Walt Disney's Illegitimate Birth?
subtitle: Was Walt Disney born out of wedlock to a woman from Almeria, Spain?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Walt Disney was an illegitimate child, born out of wedlock to a woman from a town near Almeria in southern Spain and adopted by Flora and Elias Disney.
